audio_caption: The clip begins with gentle, dreamy instrumental music, creating an anticipatory mood. A male speaker with a measured tone begins speaking, setting the scene for the annual Sibos Conference in London. He notes that London has "long been the heart of the global financial system", and promises to outline the Bank of England's "ambitious plan to support your efforts to create the future of finance". Then, the music transitions and ends.

The clip begins with a male speaker addressing a conference, noting the increasing digitization of the world and the need for "a new finance" to serve the digital economy, one that balances innovation with resilience and requires a "new Bank of England." His tone is formal and articulate. He then says he will take a few moments to expand.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the digital economy and its impact on commerce. He mentions that online sales are increasing and cash usage is declining, and describes the demands this new economy places on the financial system. He speaks in a measured, formal tone. Following the speaker, there is a short pause.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing commercial banks having direct access to the core payment system, RTGS, noting that it is becoming "increasingly anachronistic". He mentions the bank making it easier for a "broader set of firms" to compete with banks. He highlights that they are the "first G20 central bank" to do so and that there are "another 20 firms looking to join". Speaking in a confident, informative tone, he adds that RTGS will provide "API access to users to read and write payments data". The speech continues, concluding with the standardization of payment formats.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the bank's utilization of the RTGS rebuild to promote more competitive, platform-based finance for SMEs. He describes SMEs as the "engine room of our economy," adding that a significant portion do not plan to use external finance due to the perceived hassle of applying to banks. The speaker continues, noting that a substantial percentage of those who have approached their bank have been rejected.

The audio features a male speaker discussing the challenges SMEs face in borrowing against intangible assets like brand value or user base, contrasting them with traditional physical assets. He notes the lack of credit track records for SMEs and suggests that in today's data-rich world, this shouldn't be a problem. He then emphasizes the need for SMEs to identify and share relevant data with potential finance providers. He mentions the Bank of England's initiative to create an open platform for SME lending in the UK, aiming to streamline access to finance.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the Bank of England consulting on opening access to its own balance sheet to new payment providers, emphasizing that expanding access can improve monetary policy, increase competition, and support financial stability, while also improving services, cutting costs, and speeding delivery for UK households and businesses. He then highlights the enormous potential for transformation in retail payments. The speaker maintains a measured and informative tone throughout.

The clip features one male speaker discussing stablecoins, emphasizing their potential to improve financial inclusion and reduce payment costs if designed and regulated well. The speaker speaks in a neutral and informative tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing how the Bank of England is approaching innovations such as stable coins. He states they have "an open mind, but not an open door", and they want to make sure that solving one problem doesn't "inadvertently create other more systemic ones". He argues that the "terms of engagement" for payment innovations must be adopted in advance of any launch and they want to engage early on with innovators. Background music with a calm and slightly melancholic tone plays throughout the speech.

A man speaks in a formal, authoritative tone, stating that "systemically important payment systems will have to meet the highest standards" and outlining regulations related to anti-money laundering, data protection, and operational resilience. He mentions that the Bank of England is helping to lead in these areas through forums like the G7, FSB, and BIS. Then, he says he will now "turn to strengthening the system in the face of new risks".

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing the importance of data in financial services, stating "the key competitive advantage" is data collection and analysis. He describes the use of cloud and AI technologies for "leaner, faster, and more tailored financial services", noting that "almost one third of all UK payments activities" are cloud hosted. His tone is informative and professional. He adds that banking is a "second biggest global spender on AI systems" and claims these savings can be passed to customers. The audio then transitions to a new, unidentifiable sound.

The audio clip features a single male speaker expressing the Bank of England's openness to cloud adoption and AI, emphasizing the need to manage associated risks. He mentions an upcoming supervisory statement outlining their new approach. The overall tone is informative and professional.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing the PRA's exploration of new technologies to streamline compliance and regulatory processes. He gives the example of the Bank of England receiving a large amount of data, with a comparison of the magnitude of reviewing it all to the effort required to read the complete works of Shakespeare twice a week every week of the year.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that while cloud and AI have reduced costs, regulatory submissions remain labor-intensive and costly, perhaps between two and four and a half billion pounds every year. He further asserts that there are opportunities for more efficient processes, including simplifying rules, pulling data from firms, and using machine learning and AI to analyze data. This is followed by a brief, high-pitched electronic sound.

The audio begins with a male speaker outlining a bank's new review of regulatory data processes and their plans for proofs of concept with firms. The speaker describes automating data extraction, using AI and ML for analysis, and encourages collaboration with interested parties, highlighting that this is a "rich area for FinTech innovation" and then adds that he's going to conclude.

The audio clip features a male speaker with a formal and authoritative tone, discussing the potential of "the new finance" to unlock growth and the role of the Bank of England in enabling this. He emphasizes the importance of competition and resilience in the financial system. He concludes by stating the need and desire to engage with the audience.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker announcing, "During this conference, you'll be seeing more of us on Sibos TV." He adds jokingly, "Not more of me, thankfully for you." He then mentions Bank of England colleagues participating in panels and hosting teachings during the day for attendees to ask questions about their plans. The speaker's tone is professional and slightly humorous.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who sounds optimistic and says that his colleagues look forward to speaking to, and learning from, their audience. He continues with an appeal to improve finance for everyone, emphasizing that finance is not an end in itself, but a tool for households and entrepreneurs, and it is used to achieve a sustainable, inclusive, and prosperous future. He ends by thanking everyone and inviting them to enjoy the conference. Afterward, a short burst of upbeat music with electronic elements and a positive, motivational tone plays to conclude the clip.
